history.content:
I'm taking it right now and it's quite light for an upper div technical elective. This semester lectures are webcast, but in the past it hasn't been. There are 4 "modules" which each have their own midterm at the end, though it's more like a unit test than a midterm. The questions are very standard and very similar to those seen on homeworks, and also the 4th "unit test" is during the final exam slot, and none of them are cumulative. There are also weekly homeworks, which don't take super long to do. It's a good class, so I'd recommend it!

(EDIT) Above answer is good but I'd like to add a bit: every semester the professor teaching it rotates within the linguistics department so the format changes all the time depending on who is teaching, and the same goes for grading scheme. When I took it there was one quiz, midterm, and final all of which were accumulative. Weekly homework was mainly based on reading and section material so you had to keep up every week instead of just lecture. Take it if you're interested in the material, but I would say the workload varies across different semesters.

children.subject: Much much less. I literally spend no more than 5 hours per week (including lectures) in it and still got an A
Any idea of how the workload compares to, say, 61A/61B/DATA 100?

history.content: Can anyone share how it's like taking LINGUIS 100? How is the workload and difficulty? I don't find much information about it here.
history.subject: LINGUIS 100 workload and difficulty
